choices.text: Omit the morning dose of both insulin and glimepiride and continue antihypertensives
Omit all medications on the day of surgery
Continue all medications on the day of surgery
Omit insulin, glimepiride and telmisartan and continue amlodipine on the day of surgery

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient who is a known case of diabetes and hypertension is posted for an elective laparoscopic hernioplasty and takes regular insulin and oral glimepiride for his diabetes and tablet telmisartan and amlodipine for his hypertension. What would be the pre-operative advice you will give to this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

questions.text: Which of the following is not an antiemetic?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Anti emetics used peri operatively are:
a)	Metoclopramide
b)	Domperidone
c)	Ranitidine
d)	Ondansetron
e)	PPIs( pantoprazole. Omeprazole)
f)	Aprepitant ( Neurokinin antagonist)
g)	Dexamethasone

Sodium citrate is a antacid used to increase the ph of the gastric contents and is not an anti emetic

choices.text: His bag and mask ventilation will be easy, but it will be a difficult intubation
His intubation will be difficult, but bag and mask ventilation will be easy
His intubation will be easy but difficult to comment on bag and mask ventilation
His intubation and bag and mask ventilation will be both difficult.

questions.text:
A patient comes to pre anesthesia OPD and on airway examination of his oral cavity the anesthesiologist was able to see the hard palate, the soft palate, and the base of uvula was visible along with the tongue. Also, the patient was edentulous and was obese with a BMI of 35 kg\m2.
What would be his interpretation of above findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

•	Mallampati proposed a classification system (Mallampati score) to correlate the oropharyngeal space with the ease of direct laryngoscopy and tracheal intubation.
•	With the observer at eye level, the patient holds the head in a neutral position, opens the mouth maximally, and protrudes the tongue without phonating. 
•	The airway is classified according to the visible structures 
Class I: The soft palate, fauces, uvula, and tonsillar pillars are visible.
Class II: The soft palate, fauces, and uvula ( except tip )are visible.
Class III: The soft palate and base of the uvula are visible.
Class IV: The soft palate is not visible.
Class I and II are considered to be easy intubations
Class III and IV are difficult intubations

Predictors of difficult Bag and Mask ventilation are:
O: obese ( BMI>30 kg\m2)
B: bearded individual
E: edentulous ( no teeth )
S: history of Snoring ( obstructive sleep apnea)
E: elderly ( age>55 years)
•	In this scenario both predictors of difficult intubation and mask ventilation are evident so both can be expected to be difficult.

choices.text: Thyromental distance of more than 6.5 cms
Hyomental distance of more than 3 finger breadth
Sternomental distance of more than 12.5 cms
Interincisor distance of more than 3 finger breadth

questions.text: Which of the following is most important predictor of difficult laryngoscopy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

•	Sterno mental distance is the linear distance between the mentum and the manubrium sterni. 
•	A value of more than 12.5 cms is considered to be normal and less then that is a predictor of difficult intubation.
•	Sternomental distance also known as SAVVA test is the most important predictor of difficult airway.
II: MONITORING UNDER ANESTHESIA

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient is posted for laparoscopic hernia surgery and is induced with propofol and scoline for intubation. After securing the airway, the patient is given atracurium for muscle relaxation and morphine for analgesia. Soon after that following capnograph was observed. What is your interpretation of the clinical scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

•	The drugs used in the questions gives us a clue to diagnosis.
•	Both atracurium and morphine release histamine and so can cause bronchospasm
•	Bronchospasm is an obstructive lung condition and there is difficulty in expiration causing steep upstroke on capnography whos shape can be described a “ sharkfin appearance”

choices.text: Vital signs like respiration, heart rate

questions.text: Which of the following is used to monitor depth of anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

BIS or BISpectral index is a frontal processed EEG.
It measures the depth of anesthesia 
The scale ranges from 0-100 and the values tell us about the depth of anesthesia
100: awake patient
80: light sedations
60: GA
40: Deep GA
20: burst suppression
0: Flat line or isoelectric eeg

questions.text: Which combination of leads is best to diagnose intraoperative myocardial ischemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

•	ECG is the most common non-invasive monitor for detecting intraoperative ischemia.
•	Since a 12 lead ecg is not possible to monitor intraoperatively therefore we use a combination of 3 or 5 leads.
•	Of these a combination of lead V4, V5, II gives best results with 98% ischemia detection rate.

questions.text: Which is the most common used method to detect CO2 in capnography?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

•	Infra-red spectrographs are more compact and less expensive than the other methods of measurement. 
•	This has been the most popular technique for monitoring C02.

questions.text: Each of the following will cause erroneous readings by dual-wavelength pulse oximeters EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

•	The presence of hemoglobin species other than oxyhemoglobin can cause erroneous readings by dual wavelength pulse oximeters. 
•	Hemoglobin species such as carboxyhemoglobin and methemoglobin, dyes such as methylene blue and indocyanine green, and some colors of nail polish will cause erroneous readings.
•	Because the absorption spectrum of fetal hemoglobin is similar to that of adult oxyhemoglobin, fetal hemoglobin does not significantly affect the accuracy of these types of pulse oximeters. 
•	High levels of bilirubin have no significant effect on the accuracy of dual-wavelength pulse oximeters 

III: INDUCTION AGENTS

questions.text: Pain at the intravenous site is LEAST with which IV drug?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

•	Pain with the intravenous injection is common with diazepam, etomidate, methohexital, and propofol.
•	It is very rare after thiopental and ketamine 
•	Maximum pain on injection is seen with etomidate.

choices.text: Augments the CO2 responsiveness of the cerebral vasculature

questions.text: Ketamine
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

•	Ketamine is thought to increase CBF and, consequently, CBV and ICP, by two mechanisms: there may be a direct effect on cerebral vascular smooth muscle to cause vasodilation
•	there may be a “coupled” effect caused by an increase in CMR.

questions.text: Which of the following is an effect of use of etomidate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

•	Etomidate causes dose dependant inhibition of 11 beta hydroxylase enzyme which is involved in cortisol synthesis and so causes adrenocortical suppression.
•	Therefore long term infusion of etomidate in ICU for sedation is to be avoided.

questions.text: Which of the following, when given as an induction agent, causes the least amount of respiratory depression
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

•	Ketamine is a potent bronchodilator
•	Ketamine causes least respiratory depression and max analgesia
•	It increased the airway secretions as well. 
•	All the other mentioned agents cause respiratory depression
IV: MUSCLE RELAXANTS

questions.text: Most common agent used to expediate the recovery from the action of non-depolarising muscle relaxants is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

•	NDMRs are competitive inhibitors at nicotinic acetylcholine receptors.
•	The action of NDMRs is terminated by their metabolism and thus decrease in their concentration at the receptor
•	This termination of action can be expediated by administration of a cholinesterase inhibitor that will increase the acetylcholine concentration at the receptor, and this increase the speed of reversal of muscle relaxation.
•	Many cholinesterase inhibitors can be used of which neostigmine is the most commonly used drug
•	Others are physostigmine and edrophonium.
•	These drugs are non-specific and so they increase the acetylcholine at both nicotinic as well as muscarinic receptors and cause lot of muscarinic side effects.
•	To avoid them, these drugs are always co-administered with an anticholinergic e.g. glycopyrrolate or atropine

questions.text: Most common pattern of stimulation used for monitoring neuromuscular junction is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

•	There are multiple patterns of stimulation used during neuromuscular monitoring using a peripheral nerve stimulator.
•	These are single twitch, train of four, double burst stimulation and tetany
•	Of these, the most commonly used patterns is train of four (TOF).
•	In TOF stimulation 4 stimulations are given in 2 secs.

questions.text: Which of the following combination is the fastest and shortest acting muscle relaxant respectively?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

•	Fastest onset among muscles relaxants: scoline ( 30-60 secs)
•	Shortest acting muscle relaxant : scoline ( less than 10 mins)
•	Fastest onset NDMR: rocuronium ( 60-90 secs)
•	Shortest acting NDMR : mivacurium ( 15-20 mins)

questions.text: Which of the following doesn’t cause pain on injection except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Of all muscle relaxants, rocuronium is the only agent that causes pain on injection.

choices.text: Acute administration increases MAC; chronic administration decreases MAC

questions.text: Pregnancy
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

•	Pregnancy lowers MAC
•	This may be related to the sedative effects of progesterone.  
•	Pregnant patients also are very sensitive to local anesthetics

questions.text: Which is the fastest inhaled anesthetic agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

•	Speed of onset and recovery of inhaled anesthetic agent is an inverse function of its blood gas partition coefficient.
•	Among liquid volatile anesthetic agents desflurane with a blood gas partition coefficient of 0.42 is least soluble agent and so fastest onset and recovery from anesthesia
•	Slowest being methoxyflurane with a B:G coefficient of 15

questions.text: What is the principle on which the flowmeter works:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

•	Flowmeter is a device on the anesthesia machine that measures the flow of carrier gases going to the patient.
•	It is comprises of a conical pyrex glass tube called as the “ Thorpe’s tube” which has a bobbin \ float inside it that is used to measure the flow
•	Because of its tapered nature the principle of working is variable orifice and constant pressure.

questions.text: Which circuit is best for controlled ventilation in adults:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Summary of Mapleson Circuits:
•	Mapleson A: also known as Magill’s cicuit
•	best for spontaneous ventilating patients
•	Its coaxial variant is called as the “ LACK’S CIRCUIT”
•	Mapleson B : obsolete
•	Mapleson C: obsolete and also known as “ Water’s to and fro canister”
•	Mapleson D: also known as Bain’s circuit
•	Most commonly used circuit
•	Best for controlled ventilation
•	It is a coaxial circuit
•	Mapleson E & F: circuit used for pediatric patients ( weight < 20 kgs)
•	Both are valveless circuits
•	Best for both spontaneous and controlled ventilation

questions.text: Which oxygen delivery device can provide the highest possible FiO₂ in a spontaneously breathing patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation: A non-rebreather mask with a reservoir bag and one-way valves can deliver nearly 100% FiO₂ when set at 10-15 L/min flow rate, making it the most effective device for high oxygen delivery in spontaneously breathing patients.

choices.text: Severe asthma exacerbation with altered sensorium

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is the most appropriate indication for initiating BiPAP therapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Explanation: BiPAP (Bilevel Positive Airway Pressure) is indicated in conditions like acute pulmonary edema, COPD exacerbations, and hypoxic respiratory failure where non-invasive ventilation can improve oxygenation and ventilation without intubation. It is contraindicated in conditions like altered consciousness, untreated pneumothorax, or when airway protection is compromised.

questions.text: Which parameter is fixed in the volume-controlled mode of mechanical ventilation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Explanation: In volume-controlled ventilation (VCV), the ventilator delivers a fixed tidal volume regardless of airway pressures. Peak pressures may vary based on lung compliance and airway resistance.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the mode of ventilation where the ventilator delivers pressure support during spontaneous breaths but does not initiate mandatory breaths?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation: Pressure Support Ventilation (PSV) assists each spontaneous breath by delivering a preset pressure level. The ventilator does not initiate mandatory breaths in this mode, making it ideal for weaning patients who can breathe spontaneously but need minimal support.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common route of loss of heat during surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

•	The order of loss of heat from the patient during surgery and anesthesia is
•	Radiation > convection > conduction > evaporation

questions.text: Most common cause of intraoperative anaphylaxis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

•	The most common etiology of intraop anaphylaxis is
•	ANTIBIOTICS > MUSCLE RELAXANTS > CHLORHEXIDINE

choices.text: Sudden and abrupt rise of end tidal CO2 levels on capnography

questions.text: Which is the 1st manifestation of malignant hyperthermia intraoperatively?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) Clinical manifestations of malignant hyperthermia are:

Out of these the earliest and most sensitive indicator of MH is sudden and abrupt rise of ETCO2.

questions.text: All of the following are ester type of local anesthetic except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

•	Local anesthetic molecules comprise of aromatic benzene ring and a tertiary amine.
•	Both of these are joined by an intermediate chain.
•	Based on the chemical structure of this intermediate chain, local anesthetics are divided into 2 types:
1: ester local anesthetics: eg procaine, benzocaine, tetracaine, chloroprocaine 
2: amide local anesthetics: eg lignocaine, bupivacaine, prilocaine, ropivacaine

questions.text: Which state of local anesthetic molecule is required for its action:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

•	Local anesthetics are Na+ channel blockers.
•	The site of action is the intracellular surface of the channel.
•	For the drug to reach its site of action it needs to be in unionized form i.e lipophilic form to cross the cell membrane.
•	But the active form of LA is its ionized form and it is present around receptor intracellularly

choices.text: Reversible inhibitor of Na-K ATPase pump
Irreversible inhibitor of Na-K ATPase pump

questions.text: Which describes the mechanism of action of local anesthetic the best?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Local anesthetics are reversible inhibitors of sodium channels on nerve membrane.

questions.text: Which is the longest acting local anesthetic?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: The “snap” felt just before entering the epidural space represents passage through which ligament?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) • The structures that are traversed by a needle placed in the midline prior to the epidural space are as follows: • skin, subcutaneous tissue, supraspinous ligament, interspinous ligament, and ligamentum flavum. • The ligamentum flavum is tough and dense, and a change in the resistance to advancing the needle is often perceived and to many feels like a “snap.”

questions.text: Which of the following is not a method to confirm epidural space?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

•	Epidural space is a potentially negative space and its contents are epidural fat\ vessels\ spinal nerves
Methods used to identify epidural space are:
•	Loss of resistance to normal saline\ air (most common)
•	Hanging drop method
•	Ultrasonography

questions.text: Local anesthetic may cause all the following except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

	Anaphylaxis can be due to amino ester type of local anaesthetics which produce paramino benzoic acid on metabolism which is allergic.
	Local anaesthetics can cause 2 types of toxicity:
1: Methemoglobinemia: this is complication of large doses of prilocaine and benzocaine which on metabolism produce ortho-toludine which converts haemoglobin to methaemoglobin.
2: Local Anesthetic Systemic Toxicity (LAST)
Etiology: Toxic dose of local anesthetic \ mistakenly intravascular administration of the drug
CNS toxicity: Seizures and Respiratory depression
CVS toxicity: Arrythmias and Cardiac arrests

choices.text: Rush the patient to the operating room for urgent craniotomy
Monitor the patient for respiratory depression
Reassure the patient that this type of headache is normal after delivery

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient G2P2 on a postpartum day 2 complaints about having an "intense headache." The patient reports that the headache started in the morning and describes it as an intense frontal headache, severity 7/10, improves with lying down, worsens with sitting up, accompanied by blurry vision, nausea, and tinnitus, and not relieved by acetaminophen. The patient had an uneventful lower segment caesarean section under sub arachnoid block. Which of the following actions is the most appropriate for this patient's current presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
•	Post dural puncture headaches are common after a dural tap.
•	The presentation is a typical positional headache, aggravated by sitting, standing and straining.
•	Management is always 1st line symptomatic management along with reassurance that this is a normal phenomenon.
•	Last line of management is epidural blood patch

questions.text: A 65-year-old male is on a short ladder changing a light and suddenly collapses. He is unresponsive. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

INITIATING CHAIN OF SURVIVAL
Early initiation of BLS has been shown to increase the probability of survival for a person dealing with cardiac arrest.
To increase the odds of surviving a cardiac event, the rescuer should follow the steps in the Adult Chain of Survival (Figure 1).
Initiation of the Chain of Survival, which is to call 911, is the first step in the treatment of this person.

choices.text: Depends on his oxygen saturation level

questions.text: A 55-year-old male was successfully resuscitated after cardiac arrest. His pulse has returned, but he remains apneic. What is the recommended ventilation rate for this patient during post-resuscitation care?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

•    This is not a case of cardiac arrest but a case of respiratory arrest and so we only need to provide rescue breaths to the patient.
•    Most experts recommend a ventilation rate of 10 breaths per minute for adults.

questions.text: After delivering a shock, what is the next step in CPR?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

•	Immediately after delivery of the shock , the rescuer should resume CPR without wasting time in checking for pulse and respiration.
•	After 2 mins of CPR then the rhythm is assessed again.
•	This is done to minimize the delay in chest compressions.

choices.text: Clear the person and deliver the shock.
Deliver two additional minutes of CPR before delivering the shock.
Assume error and do not deliver shock.

questions.text: The AED indicates “Shock.” What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

•	Clear the person and deliver the shock. 
•	Do not delay delivery of a shock to perform additional CPR. 
•	All responders should be clear of the person when a shock is delivered. 
•	Do not assume error or delay administration of a shock.
